citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The IACUC meeting minutes and the corresponding report to the Institutional Official (IO) show that only one member of
the IACUC committee participated in the December 2023 semiannual inspection of the registrant's facility. Failure to
adequately inspect the facility can result in inaccurate semiannual reports to the IO who is ultimately responsible for
compliance with the Animal Welfare Act.
When conducting the evaluations and inspections to prepare the reports to the IO, the IACUC may determine the best
means of conducting evaluations of the research facility's programs and facilities as long as no Committee member
wishing to participate in any evaluation conducted under this subpart may be excluded. The IACUC may use
subcommittees composed of at least two Committee members and may invite ad hoc consultants to assist in conducting
the evaluations. To be corrected by 22 April 2024 and with all future program and facility reviews and semiannual reports
to the IO.

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The one active protocol for ongoing activities involving the animal at this facility is an observational study of enrichment in
a nonhuman primate. The IACUC has approved this ongoing protocol with no written assurance from the Principal
Investigator that the activities do not unnecessarily duplicate previous experiments. Failure to require this assurance can
result in unnecessary use of animals in research. The IACUC must determine that the proposed activities or significant
changes in ongoing activities meet the all requirements including that the principal investigator has provided written
assurance that the activities do not unnecessarily duplicate previous experiments. To be corrected by 22 April 2024

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The one protocol to document ongoing activities involving the animal at this facility is an observational study of enrichment
in a nonhuman primate. The IACUC has approved this ongoing activity without a rationale for the appropriateness of this
species or for the number of animals used. Failure to require this information can result in inappropriate use of animals in
research and unsatisfactory scientific outcomes. The IACUC must ensure that a proposal to conduct an activity involving
animals contains all required information including a rationale for involving animals, and for the appropriateness of the
species and numbers of animals to be used. To be corrected by 22 April 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the registrant.
